title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
Recall
¬†
The \(p\)-value is defined by thinking about what our observations would be by chance if we presuppose that the null hypothesis is in fact true:

\[ p = \mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{we observe a difference} \mid \textrm{there is no difference}) \]



This is convenient to use, because we can always impose the null hypothesis by shuffling our data. This is called permutation testing.

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
N.B.: The \(p\)-value can be thought of as
\[ p = \mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{test }+ \mid \textrm{actually }-) \]

Because there are only two test outcomes, \(+\) and \(-\), this means that
\[\begin{eqnarray*}
p & = & 1 - \mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{test }- \mid \textrm{actually }-) \\
& = & 1 - \mathrm{specificity}
\end{eqnarray*}\]


So, the \(p\)-value is in the same ‚Äúfamily‚Äù of measures about a test as sensitivity and specificity.

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:

rtpcr_sensitivity = 0.733
# https://www.uptodate.com/contents/covid-19-diagnosis
rtpcr_specificity = 0.97

# September 2023: These characteristics haven't appreciably changed

# September 2024: "

section: Do you think this will scale well?
text:
Do you think this will scale well?

Suppose quarantine lasts for 10 days (8 work days). What fraction of the workforce would have to be quarantining at any given moment from false positive tests alone?

¬†


# 10 days is the policy, but a couple of those will be a weekend
quarantine_workdays = 8
# False positives *do not* have Covid *and* test positive
quarantine_fp_per_day = np.sum( ~has_covid & rtpcr_positive )
quarantine_fp_simultaneous = quarantine_fp_per_day * quarantine_workdays
quarantine_fraction = quarantine_fp_simultaneous / n_employees

print( f'> Fraction of workforce quarantined: **{quarantine_fraction * 100:0.2f}%**' )



Fraction of workforce quarantined: 23.57%

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
But, n.b.! This test also has an extremely high accuracy‚Äîthat is, the probability of the test being correct:


# == operates element by element on arrays
# `a == b` is an array where each element is `True` if the
# corresponding elements of `a` and `b` are equal
accuracy_naive = np.sum( has_covid == rtpcr_positive ) / len( has_covid )

print( f'> Naive accuracy: **{accuracy_naive * 100:0.2f}%**' )



Naive accuracy: 96.94%





The accuracy of the test is hiding the fact that we‚Äôre actually doing quite a terrible job with the positive predictive value‚Äîthe much more actionable piece of information‚Äîbecause the prevalence of Covid cases is so low!

section: A better way to use Covid tests
text:
A better way to use Covid tests

¬†
In our simulation, the prevalence of Covid was thought of as the probability that someone in our sample had Covid. We took this to be the prevalence of Covid in San Francisco, under the assumption that we were testing people essentially randomly, and had no criteria for how we were selecting people to test.

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
section: A better way to use Covid tests
text:
A better way to use Covid tests


After briefly quarantining a substantial portion of its workforce, UCSF has decided to try a new Covid testing schema.


In medicine, we call this ‚Äúcontinual improvement‚Äù!



Now, only people who have an exposure to a confirmed symptomatic case will be tested.

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
section: A better way to use Covid tests
text:
A better way to use Covid tests

Before, we had no clue about the people being tested. This new criterion means we have more knowledge (of the exposure).

This knowledge changes our prior belief‚Äîbefore even running the test!‚Äîof whether or not the person being tested has Covid: we expect that someone who has had an exposure is more likely to have Covid than someone random from the general population.

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
section: A better way to use Covid tests
text:
A better way to use Covid tests

All of the characteristics of the test itself are still exactly the same‚Äîthe same reagents, the same technique, everything.
The only thing we‚Äôll change to simulate this new scenario is the proportion of tested people who have Covid.


Let‚Äôs say that an exposure to a symptomatic case of Covid carries an associated risk of infection of 5%:

covid_belief_sus = 0.05

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
section: What do you think will happen to the PPV of our test in this new scheme?
text:
What do you think will happen to the PPV of our test in this new scheme?

¬†
How about the NPV?

Dummy check, round 2





fig, ax = plt.subplots( figsize = (12, 1.2) )
sample_plot( ax, has_covid_sus, rtpcr_positive_sus )

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
Aha!


¬†
The PPV has jumped dramatically, from about 10% to about 60%!


In this setting‚Äîwhere we have some additional knowledge about who we‚Äôre testing‚Äîthe same exact test has become a lot more useful.

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
N.B.: There is no free lunch, of course!
The cost we pay is that the NPV in this scenario is now slightly lower!

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
The critical takeaway message is this:


How useful a test is depends on our prior belief about the thing we‚Äôre testing for.

text:
How much knowledge do we need?

Let‚Äôs see how this whole picture plays out as we ‚Äúsweep through‚Äù a bunch of different possible priors.

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
What does a test do?


¬†
Before we ran the test, we had some prior knowledge about whether we had Covid:
\[ \mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{actually }+) \]

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
What does a test do?
When we get new knowledge‚Äîthe result of the test‚Äîwe update our belief of whether we have Covid. Our knowledge about whether we have Covid after the update caused by the test is precisely the PPV:
\[\begin{eqnarray*}
&\mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{actually }+) & \\
& \downarrow & \\
& \mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{actually }+ \mid \textrm{test }+) &
\end{eqnarray*}\]
This is also known as the posterior probability (as in, the probability that we have after) given a positive test.

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
N.B.: The amount of information provided by a test result is called the result‚Äôs Bayes factor, \(K\).

While the PPV‚Äîwhich is the posterior probability of disease given a positive test‚Äîchanges depending on the prior, the following ratios are always proportional:
\[ \frac{\mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{actually }+ \mid \textrm{test }+)}{\mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{actually }- \mid \textrm{test }+)} = K\,\frac{\mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{actually }+)}{\mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{actually }-)}\]


So, the Bayes factor tells us how much receiving a positive test result changes our prior belief. Test results with larger Bayes factors change our beliefs more.

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
Tests in science
¬†
For Covid testing, we obtained some bit of noisy data (a positive test result), and sought to infer something about what was actually happening (whether we truly have Covid).

We made this inference quantitative using the Covid RT-PCR test‚Äôs PPV:
\[ \mathrm{PPV} = \mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{actually }+ \mid \textrm{test }+) \]

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
Tests in science

¬†
In science, we use statistical tests.

Just like the Covid RT-PCR, statistical tests are noisy bits of data. What we would like to do is to infer something about what is actually happening in the world on the basis of these test results.

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
Example‚ÄîCorrelation
Let‚Äôs say that you‚Äôre analyzing some data. You plug two variables you‚Äôre working on, x and y, into a magic black box like scipy.stats.pearsonr, and it pops out:
¬†

>>> scipy.stats.pearsonr( x, y )
(0.21365304326850618, 0.03281172835181021)

(The first value is the correlation \(r\), the second is the \(p\)-value.)




Cool, it‚Äôs significant! We got a positive test result.

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
Example‚ÄîCorrelation
¬†
Given this:
>>> scipy.stats.pearsonr( x, y )
(0.21365304326850618, 0.03281172835181021)
¬†
‚Ä¶ what do you now know about whether there is actually a relationship between x and y?

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
Example‚ÄîCorrelation
¬†
>>> scipy.stats.pearsonr( x, y )
(0.21365304326850618, 0.03281172835181021)
This information, by itself, is not a statement about whether the null hypothesis is actually true or false‚Äîjust as a positive Covid test is not, by itself, a statement about whether you actually have Covid.

¬†
We must infer the truth from the test



What does this inference depend on?

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
Example‚ÄîCorrelation
¬†
>>> scipy.stats.pearsonr( x, y )
(0.21365304326850618, 0.03281172835181021)
With our shiny positive test result, what we really care about is the posterior probability, given we saw this test result, of whether there is a relationship between x and y. This is precisely the PPV:
\[ \mathrm{PPV} := \mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{actually a relationship} \mid \textrm{test rejects null hyp.}) \]

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
Example‚ÄîCorrelation
¬†
>>> scipy.stats.pearsonr( x, y )
(0.21365304326850618, 0.03281172835181021)
\[ \mathrm{PPV} := \mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{actually a relationship} \mid \textrm{test rejects null hyp.}) \]
But, just as before with Covid RT-PCR,
PPV depends on our prior knowledge of whether there is a real relationship between x and y‚Äî
not just the characteristics of pearsonr!

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
Example‚ÄîCorrelation
¬†
>>> scipy.stats.pearsonr( x, y )
(0.21365304326850618, 0.03281172835181021)
Suppose I got this result by going out into the world and running the pearsonr function between every pair of two datasets I could get my hands on.

What is the probability that any two of those randomly chosen datasets are actually causally related to one another? That is, what is the prior,
\[ \mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{actually a relationship}) \]

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
Example‚ÄîCorrelation
¬†
>>> scipy.stats.pearsonr( x, y )
(0.21365304326850618, 0.03281172835181021)
¬†
What is the probability that any two of those randomly chosen datasets are actually causally related to one another? That is, what is the prior,
\[ \mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{actually a relationship}) \]
It is astronomically small.

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
Example‚ÄîCorrelation
¬†
>>> scipy.stats.pearsonr( x, y )
(0.21365304326850618, 0.03281172835181021)
¬†
In this experimental setup of randomly testing correlations, what is the PPV?

¬†
It is exceedingly low.

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
Example‚ÄîCorrelation
¬†
>>> scipy.stats.pearsonr( x, y )
(0.21365304326850618, 0.03281172835181021)
¬†
So, how do I interpret this result I just saw, that pearsonr rejected the null hypothesis of no relationship between x and y?

¬†
It is probably a false positive.

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
Does that mean that scipy.stats.pearsonr is a bad test?

¬†


Is Covid RT-PCR a bad test?

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
No.¬†

¬†
PPV isn‚Äôt just about the test.
PPV depends on how the test is used.

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
Recall
When looking at Covid testing, increasing our prior belief of Covid infection to just 5% raised the PPV from 5% to 60%, for the exact same test. To make the test‚Äôs results more meaningful, we used knowledge of prior exposure to Covid to choose who to test.

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
Even very weak information can dramatically improve the utility of a test!

¬†
So, how do you improve the positive predictive value of testing for significant correlations?



Choose the right questions to ask.

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
A clairvoyant mouse?
¬†
You look at your data, and you see that you reject the null hypothesis that manipulated mice do not predict the future with a \(p\)-value of 0.014.

¬†
What do you now know about whether the mouse is actually clairvoyant?


¬†
Why do you think this?

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
A clairvoyant mouse?
¬†
You look at your data, and you see that you reject the null hypothesis that manipulated mice do not predict the future with a \(p\)-value of 0.014.
¬†
What do you do with this information?

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
Tests do not tell us the truth.



¬†

We try to infer the truth from tests.

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
Because we live in a special part of the multiverse‚Äîthe part where we saw what we saw!


¬†
Tests update our beliefs about the world.

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
The predictive value of a test depends on how the test is used.


In particular, it depends on our prior knowledge of what we are testing for.

title: Gaining knowledge from tests
text:
Statistical testing is not just a matter of selecting the ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù test for a given question.

¬†
Being judicious about selecting the correct questions to apply the test to is a more powerful way to



strengthen the inferences gained through statistics;




improve the reproducibility of science; and




more responsibly use resources, like experimental animals, that we have an ethical obligation to minimize.

title: Active inference
text:
Learning about the world
¬†
The ‚Äúideal‚Äù science centers on the experimental cycle:


Start with what we currently know about the world.
Observe new data.
Use this data to make inferences that update how we view the world.

title: Active inference
text:
Recall
The amount of information provided by a test result is called the result‚Äôs Bayes factor, \(K\). While the PPV‚Äîwhich is the posterior probability of disease given a positive test‚Äîchanges depending on the prior, the following ratios are always proportional:
\[ \frac{\mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{actually }+ \mid \textrm{test }+)}{\mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{actually }- \mid \textrm{test }+)} = K\,\frac{\mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{actually }+)}{\mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{actually }-)}\]
So, the Bayes factor tells us how much receiving a positive test result changes our prior belief. Test results with larger Bayes factors change our beliefs more.

title: Active inference
text:
In experimental design
The posterior probability of a model given data changes depending on the prior.
However, the following ratios are always proportional:
\[
\frac{\mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{model }1 \mid \textrm{data we see})}{\mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{model }2 \mid \textrm{data we see})} = K\,\frac{\mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{model }1)}{\mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{model }2)}
\]
So, the Bayes factor \(K\) tells us how much receiving a positive test result changes our prior belief. Test results with larger Bayes factors change our beliefs more.

title: Active inference
text:
Principles of experimental design
¬†

All we can reasonably do is compare models.



‚ÄúAll models are wrong; some are useful.‚Äù‚ÄîJames Box



Choose comparisons that we think will tease apart the models (have a large expected Bayes factor)

¬†


Somebody has to tell a Congressional panel why taxpayer money pays for what we do.

title: Active inference
text:
What‚Äôs in an experimental design
When we conduct experiments, we collect data that updates our beliefs about the world:
\[
\begin{eqnarray*}
& \mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{model}) & \\
& \downarrow & \\
& \mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{model} \mid \textrm{data})
\end{eqnarray*}
\]

When you design an experiment, you specify:



what data you will collect, and
how that will update your beliefs about your model with any outcome.

title: Active inference
text:
Science:


¬†
\[
\begin{eqnarray*}
    & \mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{Model }A) & \textrm{Form Prior} \\
\end{eqnarray*}
\]

title: Active inference
text:
Science:


¬†
\[
\begin{eqnarray*}
    & \mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{Model }A) & \textrm{Form Prior} \\
    & \downarrow & \textrm{Get Data} \\
\end{eqnarray*}
\]

title: Active inference
Active inference
text:
One might wonder‚Ä¶


What PPV makes a diagnostic test good? What NPV?
Is it the same for scientific tests?
Where do tests sit in a larger societal context?

i.e., What are we actually doing with the knowledge we get from tests?

Are false positives and false negatives equally bad?

Since there‚Äôs a tradeoff between PPV and NPV, which should we prioritize making as large as possible?

title: Active inference
text:
One might wonder‚Ä¶


How do we know whether our belief about the prevalence of Covid is correct?
How do we know how accurate our prior belief about a statement in science is?




Since, as we established before, these are crucial for determining how useful any test is.

title: Active inference
text: The unraveling begins‚Ä¶

title: Active inference
text:
Science as process
¬†
Do we really just do one experiment?
¬†
\[
\begin{eqnarray*}
    & \mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{Statement}) & \\
    & \downarrow & \textrm{Get Data} \\
    & \mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{Statement} \mid \textrm{Data}) &
\end{eqnarray*}
\]

title: Active inference
text:
One might wonder‚Ä¶


What does this process, \[
\mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{Statement} \mid \textrm{Data 1}, \cdots, \textrm{Data }k)
\] converge to as we do more and more experiments, \[
k \to \infty
\]
Does it converge at all?
What does this convergence depend on?

title: Active inference
text:
One might wonder‚Ä¶

¬†
Wait, how do we choose the next test to run each time?
¬†
This is a big question, so let‚Äôs think about it in the context of a few specific examples.

title: Active inference
text:
One might wonder‚Ä¶

Let‚Äôs say we update our belief with successive tests, as above, but at each step, we choose the next test such that it will maximally increase our updated probability, \(\mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{statement} \mid \textrm{tests})\).
That is, we choose the experiment that we think will give us the most evidence supporting our model.
¬†


What does this process converge to?

title: Active inference
text:
One might wonder‚Ä¶
¬†
Let‚Äôs say we update our belief with successive tests, as above, but at each step, we choose the next test completely at random.
¬†


What does this process converge to?

title: Active inference
text:
One might wonder‚Ä¶
¬†
Let‚Äôs say we update our belief with successive tests, but we are really wrong about our initial belief.


What happens to the limit of \(\mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{Statement} \mid \textrm{Data 1}, \cdots, \textrm{Data }k)\)?
Will our belief always end up in the same place at the end of the process, regardless of what we initially think?
What is the best initial belief to have?

title: Active inference
text:
Comparing models
Let‚Äôs say we update our belief with successive tests, but this time, we look at multiple candidate models; i.e., we obtain
\[
\begin{eqnarray*}
    &\mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{model 1} \mid \textrm{test 1},\cdots,\textrm{test }n) \\
    &\mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{model 2} \mid \textrm{test 1},\cdots,\textrm{test }n) \\
    &\cdots \\
    &\mathrm{Pr}(\textrm{model }k \mid \textrm{test 1},\cdots,\textrm{test }n)
\end{eqnarray*}
\]
after a sequence of \(n\) tests.

title: Active inference
text:
One might wonder‚Ä¶



¬†
Does the presence of multiple candidate models change the way we should choose the next test?

title: Active inference
text:
One might wonder‚Ä¶
In the above scheme with multiple candidate models, let‚Äôs say that the truth is not among the models that you considered.


(After all, do we have so much hubris as scientists to think that universal truth is guaranteed to be comprehensible by human models?)




What does this process converge to?
How do you interpret the result you end up at after iterating the experimental cycle a bunch?

title: Active inference
text:
One might wonder‚Ä¶
In the above scheme with multiple candidate models, let‚Äôs say that the truth is not among the models that you considered.

(After all, do we have so much hubris as scientists to think that universal truth is guaranteed to be comprehensible by human models?)


How would you even know whether you included the truth as a candidate model you were considering in your prior?

title: Active inference
text:
History dependence
The process of updating our beliefs about our model is kind of like an optimization problem.
Imagine that there is some ‚Äúlandscape‚Äù painted across the space of all models we‚Äôre considering, with the ‚Äúheight‚Äù at each point (each model) corresponding to the ‚Äúbadness‚Äù of that model.

For example, models are worse (higher up) if they have a bigger prediction error, lower \(R^2\), etc.

title: Active inference
text:
History dependence
The process of updating our beliefs about our model is kind of like an optimization problem.
Imagine that there is some ‚Äúlandscape‚Äù painted across the space of all models we‚Äôre considering, with the ‚Äúheight‚Äù at each point (each model) corresponding to the ‚Äúbadness‚Äù of that model.
Our goal is to incrementally update what we think the best model is, in order to someday find the lowest point in the entire landscape‚Äîthe actual best model‚Äîwhich should be the truth.

title: Active inference
text:
But‚Ä¶
¬†

After each experiment we run, we collect new data.


This new data changes how we measure the badness or goodness of a model‚Äôs fit.



After all, the model should fit the new data also!


¬†

This alters the landscape of our optimization problem.

title: Active inference
text:
One might wonder‚Ä¶


What happens if we start off very wrong about our prediction of what model is best?
Does this optimization process, iteratively deforming the landscape, converge to the truth?
If not, how can we ever ‚Äúrecover‚Äù?

title: Active inference
text: How does the optimum we converge to depend on how we choose the next data to collect?

title: Active inference
text:
One might wonder‚Ä¶


If we had started off the entire process with a vastly different initial prediction, would yet another minimum have emerged?

Is that the truth?
Which one?

How does the optimum we converge to depend on our initial beliefs?

title: Active inference
text:
One might wonder‚Ä¶

¬†


Is there a criterion for optimality that is independent of our starting position?
Can we design a scheme for conducting tests that makes us more likely to converge to that universal model, regardless of our initial beliefs?

title: Active inference
text:
One might wonder‚Ä¶
¬†


Is any of this even a problem?
As we try to design a scientific process:

Should we minimize the effect of this history dependence, the ‚Äúerosion‚Äù of the landscape?
Or is this actually an important feature of how science behaves?

title: Active inference
text:
Is the body of knowledge we have converged to through the scientific process a statement about the world we live in?
¬†


Or is it just a statement about the process itself?

title: Active inference
text:
What would scientific ‚Äútruth‚Äù look like today if we started with different structures for how we build new knowledge?
¬†


What amazing ideas have we missed out on?

¬†


Who benefits from the rules being as they are?
